title: 105_hr3478
content: The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" provides for a final settlement of the claims of the Colorado Ute Indian Tribes by agreeing to reduced water supply facilities. The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" defines key terms such as Agreement, Animas-La Plata Project, Dolores Project, and Tribe/Tribes. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE COLORADO UTE INDIAN WATER RIGHTS SETTLEMENT ACT OF 1988. After the enactment of the Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998, the Secretary will construct a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acres-feet as part of the Animas-La Plata Project. This project will also include a pumping plant, reservoir inlet conduit, and provide municipal and industrial water allocations. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 allocate water to various entities, including the Southern Ute Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute Indian Tribe, Navajo Nation, and San Juan Water Commission, with specific annual depletion limits for each. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 allocate water to entities like the Southern Ute Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute Indian Tribe, Navajo Nation, and San Juan Water Commission, with specific annual depletion limits. Tribal construction costs for the Animas-La Plata Project are nonreimbursable, and nontribal water capital obligations will be satisfied by the San Juan Water Commission paying $8,600,000. The San Juan Water Commission will pay $8,600,000, the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District will pay $4,400,000, and the State of Colorado will pay $16,000,000 as part of the cost-sharing obligation for the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement and Animas-La Plata Project. Certain nonreimbursable costs for recreation, environmental compliance, cultural resources protection, and fish and wildlife mitigation are also included. Nonreimbursable costs for recreation, environmental compliance, cultural resources protection, and fish and wildlife mitigation are included in the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement and Animas-La Plata Project. Tribal water allocations for municipal and industrial use will have operation, maintenance, and replacement costs paid by the Secretary until used by the Tribe. The Tribe is not required to reimburse the Secretary for certain costs related to water allocation. Repayment of construction costs for the Dolores Project and annual operation costs will commence when the water allocation is first used by the Tribe. The Secretary shall provide water allocations to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado, with an average annual depletion not to exceed 5,230 acre-feet of water, as requested by the District. The Secretary shall provide water allocations to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado, not to exceed 5,230 acre-feet of water annually, and to the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico, not to exceed 780 acre-feet of water annually. Additional water depletions consistent with the Endangered Species Act of 1973 may be allocated among beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project according to an agreement. The Secretary will transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries for the Animas-La Plata Project, as requested by the State Engineer. Additionally, certain reports related to the project will be treated accordingly. The April 1996 Final Supplement to the Final Environmental Impact Statement and the February 19, 1996 Final Biological Opinion for the Animas-La Plata Project will satisfy requirements under the Endangered Species Act, National Environmental Policy Act, and Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 require the completion of specified facilities and an aggregate depletion of 57,100 acre-feet of water as approved in a biological opinion. This subsection does not affect the construction of other facilities or any water use not approved by the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The completion of specified facilities and an aggregate depletion of 57,100 acre-feet of water is required by the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998, as approved by the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in the final biological opinion. The provision of water to the Tribes in accordance with this section constitutes final settlement of tribal claims to water rights on the Animas and La Plata Rivers. Nothing in this section affects the Tribes' rights to water on other streams and rivers, participation in the Animas-La Plata Project, receiving water dedicated to tribal use, or acquiring water rights under Colorado law. The Attorney General of the United States shall file necessary instruments with the District Court, Water Division Number 7 in Colorado to amend the final consent decree as per the Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998. SEC. 4. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION; TREATMENT OF CERTAIN FUNDS. The amendments made by this Act to section 6 of the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement of 1988 do not affect the applicability of other provisions of that Act or the Secretary of the Interior's obligation to deliver water from the Dolores Project and complete construction of facilities on the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservation as described in specific appropriations acts. The Department of the Interior and Related Agencies Appropriations Acts from 1993 to 1995 are referenced, along with the treatment of the uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado. This uncommitted portion can be used to assist in certain situations. The uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado, as referenced in Department of the Interior and Related Agencies Appropriations Acts from 1993 to 1995, can be used to assist in funding components of the Animas-La Plata Project not described in section 6(a)(3) of the Act.
